title: How to Paint Furniture White

steps.headline: Work on taking the furniture apart piece by piece (if applicable).
steps.description: Remove any drawers or shelf slots first, if necessary. Use a screwdriver to loosen and take off any hardware from the furniture, such as hinges and knobs. Take off the back of the furniture if you plan to paint the insides. Set the hardware aside in a box or container for safekeeping.

steps.headline: Sand your furniture with coarse (30 to 50 grit) sandpaper.
steps.description: Rub the sandpaper in a circular motion along the surface of the furniture. Use the sandpaper on every part of the furniture you plan to paint. Keep sanding until the furniture's varnish is visibly roughened all over.

steps.headline: Sand the furniture again with medium (60 to 80 grit) sandpaper.
steps.description: Move the medium sandpaper in the direction that the wood grain moves in. Continue sanding until the furniture looks smooth. Afterwards, use a wet rag to wipe down the furniture and wait around an hour for it to dry.

steps.headline: Mold water-based wood filler into any dents or holes you find in the furniture.
steps.description: You can purchase wood filler online or from your local home improvement store. It typically comes in putty form. Shape it so it fills and covers the holes in the wood. Depending on the depth of the hole, wait between 2 and 8 hours (for large holes) or 15 minutes (for small holes) before sanding the area and continuing work.

steps.headline: Assemble your workspace.
steps.description: Your workspace should be in a dry, preferably windowless area. Sunlight may harm the quality of your paint job. Make sure your workspace is large enough for you to move comfortably, as well as well ventilated to protect against fumes. Set up a lamp at an angle, so you can more easily see every area of the furniture as you paint. It should provide shadows to make it easier to spot mistakes in your paint job.

steps.headline: Sweep and vacuum up any dust left behind from your sanding.
steps.description: Let the area air out for a few hours so it can become clear of any extra dust. Afterwards, wipe off any remaining dust off of the furniture with a clean rag, using smooth, circular strokes. Lay down tarp on the floor if you can.

steps.headline: Cover any hinges and inside edges of the furniture with tape.
steps.description: If you were unable to remove any hinges from the furniture beforehand, wrap it with painter's tape. Press tape over the inside edges of the furniture, as well as any other areas you don't want to get paint on. You can also apply tape to the sides and back of the furniture. Be judicious and try to apply the tape as thoughtfully as you can.

steps.headline: Apply primer to the furniture with a roller or brush.
steps.description: Rollers are better for applying primer to large surfaces. Brushes are best for getting into tight corners or priming smaller areas. Cover the entire area you intend to paint. Use knot block primer on furniture with knotty and/or dark wood.

steps.headline: Try to apply the primer to the furniture in a thin coat.
steps.description: Keeping your primer thin will prevent dripping. Afterwards, give the primer time to dry. The primer will take between 4 and 6 hours to dry. If your primer starts to drip, simply wipe off the dripping and reapply the primer in the affected area.

steps.headline: Use latex paint.
steps.description: Latex paint is the standard for home improvement projects. When you choose your bucket of white paint, pay attention to the label. There are two different types of latex paint for furniture: indoor and outdoor. Indoor latex paint is, naturally, for indoor furniture. Outdoor latex furniture is meant for outdoor furniture, and is sturdier against the elements.

steps.headline: Apply the first coat of paint with a roller or synthetic brush.
steps.description: Keep your first layer thin, just like when you applied the primer. Try to paint one stroke at a time and make your strokes follow one direction. If you're using a roller, avoid moving it back and forth; this may create uneven areas in your paint layer. Afterwards, let the paint dry for 1 hour. If you're using brand new brushes, wet them with clean water and shake them dry. This will make it easier to use them with latex paint. If you notice drips in your paint job, you can scratch it off with a utility knife. Then add thin strokes of paint to cover the area.

steps.headline: Sand the dried paint layer with fine (100 to 180 grit) sandpaper.
steps.description: Doing this will get rid of dust or dripping. Sand each layer of paint after applying it and letting it dry. Work in gentle, circular motions.

steps.headline: Paint 3 or 4 layers to ensure an even job.
steps.description: Working in multiple coats will help the paint to be as opaque as possible. It should take around 24 hours for your final paint layer to dry. Don't apply a new layer of paint until the first has dried.

steps.headline: Add 2 coats of varnish once the final paint layer has dried.
steps.description: Work thin, just as you did with the primer. Use a soft paint brush to add the varnish, and work in unidirectional, long movements. Use fine sandpaper (100 to 180 grit) on the first layer of varnish before painting on the second.

steps.headline: Put your furniture back together.
steps.description: Let the paint and varnish dry for around 72 hours before you start putting the furniture back together. Slide the shelves or drawers back into place. Use a screwdriver to re-attach any hinges and knobs. Now you can use and enjoy your newly painted furniture!
